channel.name: Signature Verification Using Proof Systems Repo In Rust

messages.content:
Is there a way to verify signatures that are generated via `Signature.create` of `o1js` using `mina-signer` Rust crate?
https://github.com/o1-labs/proof-systems/blob/master/signer/src/lib.rs#L91

I just need to verify a signature of a message that consists of Field elements.

Do I need to implement `mina_hasher::Hashable` trait?

Or should I translate this logic into Rust?
https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/02f2ffb6a70389fba198efb161c7e04a87534c95/src/lib/signature.ts#L285

embeds.title: o1js/src/lib/signature.ts at 02f2ffb6a70389fba198efb161c7e04a87534c...
embeds.description: TypeScript framework for zk-SNARKs and zkApps. Contribute to o1-labs/o1js development by creating an account on GitHub.

embeds.title: proof-systems/signer/src/lib.rs at master · o1-labs/proof-systems
embeds.description: The proof systems used by Mina. Contribute to o1-labs/proof-systems development by creating an account on GitHub.

messages.content: at a brief glance, Hashable seems like the right thing to me
I realized that o1js hashes the message with `"CodaSignature*******"` prefix.
I am trying to reimplement the same algorithm in Rust but `hashWithPrefix` has really confused my mind.
`hashWithPrefix`: <https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/95e5d419e86be95c5fd4803d6679e2ea6aaaaea3/src/lib/hash.ts#L70>
I couldn't find an equivalent to `Posedion.update` of o1js in Rust with  `ArithmeticSponge<Fp256<FpParameters>, PlonkSpongeConstantsKimchi>`.
Neither `Poseidon<PlonkSpongeConstantsKimchi, My<'_>>::update` seems like the equivalent of `Poseidon.update`.
Oh, I see. `ArithmeticSponge::absorb` and `ArithmeticSponge::squeeze` are what I had to use.

I noticed that `hashWithPrefix` somehow modifies the inputs.
It is called with a message that contains 4 field elements, but inside `hashWithPrefix` body, that message has tens of field elements.
It looks like `genericHash` wraps `hashWithPrefix` 🤔  <https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/95e5d419e86be95c5fd4803d6679e2ea6aaaaea3/src/lib/provable-types/merkle-list.ts#L509>
o1js also creates an account update even though I am just creating a signature just in a test script without anything zkapp related.
I think the reason why the message is modified is that `genericHash` adds extra information to it.
A working example of verifying a signature that is created using o1js in Rust would really help me.

`genericHash` somehow converts the message to an account update, converts it to field elements, and then hashes the field elements with a prefix. 
I also tested it with Auro wallet and its signing mechanism does the same thing under the hood.
```js
AccountUpdate {
  label: 'Dummy',
  lazyAuthorization: undefined,
  id: 0.6796062886271668,
  body: {
    publicKey: PublicKey { x: [Field], isOdd: [Bool] },
    tokenId: Field { value: [Array] },
    update: {
      appState: [Array],
      delegate: [Object],
      verificationKey: [Object],
      permissions: [Object],
      zkappUri: [Object],
      tokenSymbol: [Object],
      timing: [Object],
      votingFor: [Object]
    },
// ...
```
It also uses `TestnetZkappBody****` instead of `CodaSignature*******` as the prefix.
`AccountUpdate.publicKey` doesn't match the public key of the private key that is creating the signature 😱
This really seems so mysterious. Let's just make inter process communications with a Node.js program to verify signatures.
Maybe this can help <https://github.com/MinaProtocol/mina/blob/master/docs/specs/signatures/description.md>
can you give me some o1js code to run as well as a Cargo.toml to help me run this?
are you using latest o1js master? you keep linking to a slightly old commit.
where do you see the TestnetZkappBody prefix used?
https://github.com/jspada/mina-signer is this what you're talking about? it does not seem maintained, sorry to say.

embeds.title: GitHub - jspada/mina-signer: The signature scheme used by Mina
embeds.description: The signature scheme used by Mina. Contribute to jspada/mina-signer development by creating an account on GitHub.

messages.content: I am modifying o1js files inside node_modules folder.
I am adding console logs everywhere 😅
This is how I can see what it does.
I am using o1js 0.17.0
No, I am talking about ‘mina-signer’ crate inside proof systems repository.
https://github.com/o1-labs/proof-systems/blob/master/signer/src/lib.rs#L91

embeds.title: proof-systems/signer/src/lib.rs at master · o1-labs/proof-systems
embeds.description: The proof systems used by Mina. Contribute to o1-labs/proof-systems development by creating an account on GitHub.

messages.content: ok but what is the actual message you are signing in o1js?
and your rust code does not have 42?
No, it createas a different signature.
ok, so that's why the signatures don't match, the input is different?
Yeah, o1js doesn't just work with `[Field(42)]` it creates an `AccountUpdate`, converts it to fields, then hashes it with a prefix.

ok, so if you have no rust code for doing that, then what are you expecting?

if you just need to verify the signature in rust, you don't need to be writing any code to create the signature in rust, you need to call verify.
i think i don't understand the problem you are facing :)
At line 270, `msg.concat([publicKey.x, publicKey.y, r])` isn't the exact message that is signed. o1js modifies the message internally to another message.
Oh, okay.
Both verification and creation uses  `hashWithPrefix` function.

The reason why I am creating a signature is that the console.log I added inside `hashWithPrefix` function's body doesn't log when `verify` is called. 
But it logs when `create` is called.
<https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/95e5d419e86be95c5fd4803d6679e2ea6aaaaea3/src/lib/signature.ts#L254>

I created signatures and verified them both by reimplementing the logic in Rust and using `Schnorr` with implementing `Hashable` trait.
But they don't do what o1js does. Because in Rust, I hash the message with a prefix. In o1js, it creates an account update and hashes it with a prefix.

I can't run any of this code snippets you are pasting locally in an easy way so unless you provide the o1js code you use to generate the signature and the rust code you use to verify it, in a way i can independently run and see the problem, it will be very hard to help

http://www.sscce.org/

embeds.title: Short, Self Contained, Correct Example
embeds.description:
Describes the short, self contained,
correct example.  A useful technique for debugging.

messages.content: If I was able to reproduce that account update creation based on the input message to be signed, then Rust version would behave the same.
Oh, sorry. Let me simplify the code and send you reproduceable samples.
thank you, i am just a lowly protocol developer, not very fast with all these SDKs :)
You can also set `Hashable::D` as `NetworkId` and use `NetworkId::TESTNET` but it still doesn't work.

I also reimplemented `Signature.verify`'s logic but it doesn't have a snippet here. 
But `hashWithPrefix` function does some magic under the hood. So I couldn't reproduce the same results.

`Signature.verify`: <https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/95e5d419e86be95c5fd4803d6679e2ea6aaaaea3/src/lib/signature.ts#L285>

# What I Want

Being able to verify signatures a user creates via Auro wallet (o1js) in Rust.

this is a required step, to make sure that the verification and the signing happen with the same ID.

and while trying to understand this issue, you added logs to o1js to print any hash inputs, and saw ZkappBody when creating hash of account update, which is different than the hash used for Signature.create
do i understand correctly your debugging effort?
That's right.
well, the snippets look reasonable, i will try pasting your snippets into a template project later.
I was able to find the thread https://discord.com/channels/484437221055922177/1092492982109872281/1092492982109872281, I've even used same input for testing lol.
